s.text: Of course, the Direct Hit study doesn't mean that no one is going to the Gore site.
Now on a Tripod home page, the site itself claims to have been hit only 1,110 times since December 1998.
"We process the data from our partners on a daily basis," says Gary Culliss, Direct Hit's chairman and co-founder.
The official site "didn't even make the top 50" choices of those who searched for Gore's name, according to a Direct Hit executive.
Direct Hit says that while it cannot detect the identity of individual Web users, it can track their movements with unprecedented precision.
Of course, the Direct Hit study doesn't mean that no one is going to the Gore site.
Of course, the Direct Hit study doesn't mean that no one is going to the Gore site.
And it's possible (though statistically unlikely) that large numbers of Web surfers using search engines not measured by Direct Hit were flocking to the Gore site.
The third-most-visited Gore site, according to Direct Hit, is an Al Gore joke repository, posted on the home page of a GeoCities member and sponsored by the Ripon College Republicans.
By contrast, Bradley's official site was the most common destination of those who entered Bradley's name into a search engine, according to Direct Hit.
Direct Hit tracked the paths of about 1,400 Web surfers who entered the names Al Gore or Bill Bradley into search engines from Oct. 22 to Oct. 27.
Direct Hit says that while it cannot detect the identity of individual Web users, it can track their movements with unprecedented precision.
Of course, the Direct Hit study doesn't mean that no one is going to the Gore site.

Although Direct Hit has yet to produce a similar traffic study for the Republican candidates, a search on its Web site shows that George W. Bush's official site is also not among the top 10 sites surfed by those entering Bush's name.
The site is actually no longer at the address that Direct Hit found to be most visited (a common problem with search engines).
Roger Salazar, a spokesman for the Gore campaign, says that he has not seen the Direct Hit study.
Direct Hit has partnerships with a large number of Web companies, including Microsoft Network, Lycos, InfoSpace, LookSmart, and others.
Direct Hit says that while it cannot detect the identity of individual Web users, it can track their movements with unprecedented precision.
Of course, the Direct Hit study doesn't mean that no one is going to the Gore site.
Of course, the Direct Hit study doesn't mean that no one is going to the Gore site.
Of course, the Direct Hit study doesn't mean that no one is going to the Gore site.
Some of the Gore-related sites that Direct Hit said were visited most by those searching for Gore material are out of date and thinly visited.
Gore's site in Spanish was among the 30 sites most often visited by those searching for his name, but Direct Hit executives say that after the top 10, there's no significant traffic worth measuring.

A recent study by Direct Hit, the Massachusetts-based company that operates a "popularity" search engine, revealed that for five days in late October, almost no one searching the Web for information about Gore actually made their way to Gore's official Web site.
Direct Hit says that while it cannot detect the identity of individual Web users, it can track their movements with unprecedented precision.
